titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid to the Norma Kidd Green papers SSC.MS.00068
titlestmt.author: Madison White

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-10-26 13:17:40 -0400.

change.item: This record was migrated from InMagic DB Textworks to ArchivesSpace.

did.abstract: The Norma Kidd Green Papers includes information regarding Grace Coppock and "First 75 Years of the YWCA" of University of Nebraska by Green.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in 1963 and 1964 by an unknown donor.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Norma Kidd Green (1893-1975) graduated from the University of Nebraska, 1915. Author of Iron Eye's Family: The Children of Joseph La Flesche (1969).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Norma Kidd Green papers, Sophia Smith Collection, SSC-MS-00068, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Mass.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: M Ed.: A Forgotten Chapter in American Education (1961) by NKG. SSC: Manuscript of"1st 15 years of the YWCA of the U. of Nebraska"and"Grace Coppock: A Person for Today"xeroxed into YWCA box 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Norma Kidd Green Papers include information regarding Grace Coppock; address at Omaha, Nebraska 1912; and "A Person for Today" by Helen Thoburn. Also "First 75 Years of the YWCA" of University of Nebraska by Green, plus Pin of Black Masque that belonged to Fannie Drake, 1906.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Materials in this collection may be governed by copyright. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. Researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.
